Article.ArticleTitle: New System for Measuring the Photochemical Ozone Production Rate in the Atmosphere.

AbstractText: We have developed a new system for measuring photochemical ozone production rates in the atmosphere. Specifically, the system measures the net photochemical oxidant (O<sub>x</sub>: the sum of ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) and nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>)) production rates (P-L(O<sub>x</sub>)). Measuring O<sub>x</sub> avoids issues from perturbations to the photostationary states between nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>) and O<sub>3</sub>. This system has "reaction" and "reference" chambers. Ambient air is introduced into both chambers, and O<sub>x</sub> is photochemically produced in the reaction chamber and not generated in the reference chamber. Air from the chambers is alternately introduced into an NO-reaction (NO: nitric oxide) tube to convert O<sub>3</sub> to NO<sub>2</sub>, and then the O<sub>x</sub> concentration is measured as NO<sub>2</sub> using a laser-induced fluorescence technique. P-L(O<sub>x</sub>) was obtained by dividing the difference in O<sub>x</sub> concentrations between air samples from the two chambers by the mean residence time of the air in the reaction chamber. In this study, the P-L(O<sub>x</sub>) measurement system was characterized, and the current detection limit of P-L(O<sub>x</sub>) was determined to be 0.54 ppbv h<sup>-1</sup> with an integration time of 60 s (S/N = 2), assuming an ambient O<sub>x</sub> concentration of 100 ppbv. Field measurements of P-L(O<sub>x</sub>) were conducted using the system at a remote forest location.
